channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Zelensky Visits Reclaimed City as Ukrainian Troops Push On
item.description: The Ukrainian president made an unannounced visit to Izium, which Kyiv’s forces seized in a lightning offensive in the northeast. Ukrainian officials said their next objective was retaking Lyman, a gateway to Russian-held Luhansk Province.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: Pakistan Suffers Record Flooding, Turning Villages Into Islands
item.description: The flooding has displace more than 33 million people, submerging vast areas of Pakistan that are likely to take months to dry out.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Zia ur-Rehman and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amira, 15, at center, is helped by her husband to walk through water on the edge of Johi town. She had given birth just a few days before.

item.title: Updates: Lines Stretch for Miles as Queen Elizabeth Lies in State
item.description: The late monarch will lie in state in Westminster for four days.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: Emergency Rooms Across Canada Close Amid Nursing Shortage
item.description: A nationwide shortage of nurses has caused dozens of emergency rooms across Canada to close temporarily and forced some patients to wait days for a bed.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: The Montfort Hospital, which mainly serves Ottawa’s French-speaking community, is one of several Ontario hospitals that temporarily closed its emergency department.

item.title: Hermès Bags and Millions in Cash: The Fall of Malaysia’s Najib Razak
item.description: The former prime minister and his wife were once seen as untouchable. Now, both have been found guilty in connection with the 1MDB financial scandal.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.media:description: Najib Razak, the former prime minister of Malaysia, arriving to court in Putrajaya, Malaysia, last month.

item.title: Top European Court Condemns France Over Refusal to Bring Home ISIS Families
item.description: Fighters’ families have been held in Kurdish-run camps in Syria for years. The court ruled that France had violated their right to return home when rejecting their requests for repatriation.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Al Hol, a detention camp in northeastern Syria, in 2019. France has long resisted calls to repatriate adult women, saying that it considered them “fighters” who should be tried in Syria and Iraq.

item.title: Xi Jinping Heads to Central Asia in First Foreign Trip Since 2020
item.description: Xi Jinping, who is expected to meet with Vladimir Putin, will seek to project confidence as a global statesman at a time of grave challenges at home.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Kazakhstan Presidential Press Office, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo released by Kazakhstan’s Presidential Press Office showed Xi Jinping, China’s leader, arriving in Nur-Sultan, Kazakhstan, on his first trip abroad since the early days of the Covid-19 pandemic, on Wednesday.

item.title: How Time Softened Judgment of Camilla and Fury Over Diana’s Death
item.description: A quarter-century ago Princess Diana’s shocking death provoked outrage at the royal family. Queen Elizabeth’s passing, in contrast, has been draped in civility and respect.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Dan Kitwood/Agence France-Presse, via Pool/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: King Charles III and Camilla, the queen consort, made an appearance on Monday before British lawmakers.

item.title: The U.S. Touts Big Investments for Mexico, Testing Its Nationalist Policies
item.description: U.S. officials are looking south for a strategic partner to create a regional manufacturing hub that can rival China. But there are still doubts over Mexico’s willingness to cater to foreign industry.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: An electronics assembly plant in Tijuana, Mexico, last year.

item.title: Challenges for Russia and China Test a ‘No-Limits’ Friendship
item.description: Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping are set to meet later this week. Russia’s battlefield losses and China’s slowdown could complicate their relationship.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher, Anton Troianovski and Jane Perlez
item.media:credit: Alexei Druzhinin/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, and China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, in Beijing in February. The two are expected to meet again this week in Uzbekistan.

item.title: Kenya Inaugurates William Ruto as President
item.description: As he took the reins of power, William Ruto promised to alleviate rising prices and strengthen the judiciary. But his team limited local television access, raising concern about press freedoms.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: William Ruto, the new Kenyan president, lifted a sword at the Moi International Sports Center during his inauguration ceremony on Tuesday.

item.title: Armenia and Azerbaijan Clash Raises Fears of Broader Conflict
item.description: The long-simmering conflict last flared in 2020, when Moscow brokered a cease-fire. Now some wonder what Russia might do next.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Armenian soldiers and a Russian peacekeeping soldier, on the vehicle, at a checkpoint in the disputed area of Nagorno-Karabakh in 2020.

item.title: Who Will Pay for Queen Elizabeth’s Funeral
item.description: The state will cover the huge price tag at a time when many in Britain are struggling to pay their bills and are bracing for a difficult winter.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: The cost of Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral has not yet been made public.

item.title: Ostracized by the West, Russia Finds a Partner in Saudi Arabia
item.description: The two oil-producing countries have extended their partnership even as the United States and Europe have sought to punish and isolate Russia for invading Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in 2019. The leaders have worked together to prop up global oil prices.

item.title: Lawmakers Tell Biden Administration to Withhold Military Aid to Egypt
item.description: Senior Democratic lawmakers said the United States must not give aid to Egypt until it improves its human rights record, in the latest instance of tensions over Middle East policies.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Tora prison on the southern outskirts of Cairo in 2020.

item.title: Why the Queen’s Coffin Will Leave Buckingham Palace at 2:22 p.m. Exactly
item.description: The procession will last 38 minutes and will “arrive at Westminster Hall at 3 p.m. on the dot.”
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Outside Buckingham Palace on Wednesday in London.

item.title: E.U.’s Top Official Details Plans For Lasting Support of Ukraine
item.description: Ursula von der Leyen’s State of the Union message asserted that the European Union would stick together against Russia despite the economic costs.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen delivered her annual message on the state of the European Union at the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, on Wednesday.

item.title: Europe Plans to Ban Goods Made With Forced Labor
item.description: While it does not explicitly mention Xinjiang, the western Chinese region where Uyghurs are believed to be pressed to work in camps, the proposal is widely seen as being aimed at Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Valdis Dombrovskis, the E.U. trade chief, said that the European Commission had been “very careful to make sure that what we are doing is compatible” with World Trade Organization rules.

item.title: Margrethe II of Denmark Is Now Reigning Queen in Europe
item.description: Though they ruled from capitals hundreds of miles apart, Queen Elizabeth and Queen Margrethe found time now and again to meet and spill the tea about family, children and other matters.
item.dc:creator: Yonette Joseph
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Keld Navntoft/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Queen Margrethe of Denmark visited the port city of Elsinore in June.

item.title: Poverty, Plunging
item.description: Child poverty in the U.S. has fallen by more than half since the early 1990s.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: Where the New Climate Law Means More Drilling, Not Less
item.description: A compromise built into the law ensures oil and gas leasing in the Gulf of Mexico for the next decade. Activists say the region has been “sacrificed” to fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Bryan Tarnowski

item.title: Read Your Way Through Helsinki
item.description: Pajtim Statovci shares his love of Finnish literature and the books that helped him, a child of immigrants, to find his voice and grow from reader to award-winning writer.
item.dc:creator: Pajtim Statovci
item.category: The Women I Think About at Night: Traveling the Paths of My Heroes (Book)

item.title: An Oily Challenge: Evict Stinky Old Furnaces in Favor of Heat Pumps
item.description: Building by building, New York and other cities are trying to stop the age-old use of fossil fuels to heat homes and buildings. In the U.S., new climate laws aim to speed things up.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Elias Williams for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tami Nelson helps install wiring for heat pumps in her 100-year-old Brooklyn brownstone.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Falling Russian morale.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vehicle used by Russian forces outside Balakliya, Ukraine.

item.title: Ukrainians Recount Frantic Russian Retreat
item.description: Residents of towns recently retaken by Ukraine described a chaotic flight by disorganized Russian troops, suggesting morale and inexperience remain major problems for Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: During a media tour arranged by the Ukrainian government of recently retaken territory, a vehicle used by Russian forces stood on the road outside Balakliya.

item.title: U.S. Rebukes Russia for Claims of Secret Bioweapons in Ukraine
item.description: Russia used a formal meeting in Geneva to air its unsupported accusations but faced considerable diplomatic pushback.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow on Tuesday. The State Department condemned Russia for repeating unfounded claims that the United States was operating secret biological labs in Ukraine.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Putin and Xi Prepare to Meet
item.description: Plus a kangaroo killed a man in Australia and “Squid Game” made history at the Emmy Awards.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, and China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, in Beijing in February. The two are expected to meet again this week in Uzbekistan.

item.title: Russia Secretly Gave $300 Million to Political Parties and Officials Worldwide, U.S. Says
item.description: A U.S. intelligence review found that Russian agencies and figures aimed to exert political influence abroad and sway elections on behalf of the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong

item.title: King Charles and Camilla Visit Northern Ireland Ahead of Queen’s Funeral
item.description: King Charles III visited Belfast and met with members of Sinn Fein, the Irish nationalist party, now the largest in the country.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: King Charles III and Camilla viewing floral tributes left outside Hillsborough Castle in Belfast, Northern Ireland, on Tuesday.

item.title: How the New Climate Law Can Save You Thousands of Dollars
item.description: Rebates and tax credits can lower the cost of solar panels, energy-efficient appliances and electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:description: The Inflation Reduction Act includes tax credits and rebates for consumers who want to install solar panels, buy an electric car and take other measures to shrink their carbon footprint.

item.title: When the Queen Died, Someone Had to Tell the Bees
item.description: A report that the royal beekeeper had informed Queen Elizabeth II’s bees of her death received some mockery, but it has been a tradition for centuries.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Putin Spokesman Says Russia Is Not Considering a New Draft
item.description: Russian commentators have been calling on President Vladimir V. Putin to bolster the army with recruits and to target Ukrainian infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A Ukrainian military vehicle on Monday in the Kharkiv region, where rapid Ukrainian gains have caused a stir in Russia.

item.title: Emmy Success for ‘Squid Game’ Is Hailed in South Korea
item.description: After the dystopian Netflix drama picked up multiple wins, Koreans celebrated the awards as the latest example of their country’s rise as a cultural powerhouse.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Lee Jung-jae, left, who won the Emmy for best actor in a drama series, and Hwang Dong-hyuk, who was honored for his directing, after an impressive showing for “Squid Game” in Los Angeles on Monday.

item.title: Fatal Kangaroo Attack Is Said to Be First in Australia in 86 Years
item.description: The police said they believed that the man had been keeping the wild animal as a pet.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Kangaroos near Canberra, Australia.

item.title: Sri Lanka Wins Cricket’s T20 Asia Cup, Bringing Joy to Fans
item.description: The men’s cricket team won the Asia Cup in the T20 format, hours after Sri Lanka won the equivalent championship in women’s netball. Both teams were feted with a parade on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Skandha Gunasekara and Mike Ives
item.media:description: Sri Lanka’s men’s cricket team was feted in the capital, Colombo, on Tuesday.

item.title: Clashes Erupt Between Armenia and Azerbaijan in Nagorno-Karabakh
item.description: The simmering conflict over the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region last flared in 2020, when Russia brokered a cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Armenian soldiers and a Russian peacekeeping soldier, on the vehicle, at a checkpoint in the disputed area of Nagorno-Karabakh in 2020.

item.title: Ukraine on the March
item.description: It’s not just one region. Ukraine is making progress in multiple places.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A Ukrainian tank in the Kharkiv region yesterday.

item.title: Xi’s China and Biden’s U.S.: It Feels Like a Cold War
item.description: Even at their worst moments, the Americans and the Soviets kept talking. Today, U.S.-China contacts are scarce, while Beijing and Moscow move closer together.
item.dc:creator: Jane Perlez
item.media:description: President Biden during a virtual meeting in November with Xi Jinping, China’s leader. They have spoken only five times since early 2021.

item.title: The Critical Moment Behind Ukraine’s Rapid Advance
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky wanted to make a dramatic move in the war against Russia. U.S. and Ukrainian officials came up with a plan.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers near the Kherson front this month.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth’s Coffin Arrives at Buckingham Palace in London
item.description: Despite a rainy evening, crowds lined the streets of London as the hearse carrying the queen’s coffin made its way to Buckingham Palace.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The coffin of Queen Elizabeth II passed throngs of people on its way into Buckingham Palace.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: More Ukrainian advances.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: How King Charles Turned His Royal Estate Into a Lucrative Portfolio
item.description: As prince, Charles used tax breaks, offshore accounts and canny real estate investments to turn a sleepy estate into a billion-dollar business.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley and Euan Ward
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles III spent years turning his royal estate into a billion-dollar portfolio.

item.title: Russian Critics Speak Out, Prompted by Ukraine Losses
item.description: Ukraine’s recent battlefield successes are emboldening Vladimir Putin’s critics and sending his supporters in search of someone else to blame.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A Russian tank abandoned in a village on the outskirts of Izium, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Sudden Gains Prompt New Questions for Commanders
item.description: Ukraine’s military is gauging how far its forces can press the attack, at risk of their ability to hold the new lines. Russian leaders are trying to regroup after a dramatic, demoralizing rout.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier standing atop an abandoned Russian tank near a village on the outskirts of Izium in eastern Ukraine on Sunday.

item.title: Key Moments in the Russia-Ukraine War: A Timeline
item.description: Here is one key battlefield development from every month of the war.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Ukraine’s Advance Continues
item.description: Plus former British colonies weigh their relationship with the monarchy and Lebanon faces blackouts.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency services responded to multiple missile strikes on a Ukrainian police station in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth’s Death: What to Expect Today as Britain Mourns
item.description: Her funeral is scheduled for Sept. 19. Before that, there are processions, vigils and four days of lying in state in London.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth’s coffin was loaded into a state hearse and driven to Buckingham Palace on Tuesday.

item.title: King Charles Pays Tribute to Queen Elizabeth on a Day Steeped in Tradition
item.description: King Charles III addressed Parliament in London, then flew to Scotland for a service of thanksgiving for his mother.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: The narrow streets of Edinburgh were thronged on Monday by well-wishers hoping to get a glimpse of the hearse carrying Queen Elizabeth II from Holyroodhouse to St. Giles’ Cathedral.

item.title: Prime Minister Liz Truss’s Dizzying First Week
item.description: Ms. Truss took over a British government facing an economic emergency. But those problems have been eclipsed by the queen’s death, an epochal event that has put politics on hold.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss speaking outside 10 Downing Street last Thursday, the day Queen Elizabeth II died in Scotland.

item.title: At 75, the Father of Environmental Justice Meets the Moment
item.description: The White House has pledged $60 billion to a cause Robert Bullard has championed since the late seventies. He wants guarantees that the money will end up in the right hands.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.category: White House Council on Environmental Quality
item.media:credit: Michael Starghill Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert Bullard doesn’t recall when people started calling him the father of environmental justice. “It’s really a compliment,” he said. “I’ve been called worse.”

item.title: Who Will Attend Queen Elizabeth II’s Funeral? Here’s What We Know.
item.description: Heads of state and royalty from around the world are expected to attend the funeral on Sept. 19.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: The state funeral for Queen Elizabeth II will be held at 11 a.m. next Monday at Westminster Abbey.

item.title: Ukraine’s Sudden Success Could Bolster Europe’s Support — and Morale
item.description: “It’s not for nothing.” Ukraine’s backers say that an offensive over the weekend shows Western military aid is helping, and that it’s time to supply more sophisticated weaponry.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: After the village of Udy in the Kharkiv region was retaken by Ukraine, mines and other weapons were recovered.

item.title: Losses in Ukraine Prompt Debate on Russian TV
item.description: The divergence of views, even on tightly-controlled state television networks, highlighted how Moscow’s narrative had quickly shifted.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin appeared on television at a bar in Moscow in February, before the invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: What Is a Constitutional Monarchy?
item.description: Even without a written constitution, Britain follows laws and carefully documented traditions that together bind the king.
item.dc:creator: Peter Robins
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III on Monday in London’s Westminster Hall. He pledged to uphold Britain’s constitutional monarchy.

item.title: The Cowboy and Queen Elizabeth
item.description: A renowned American horse trainer described his three-decade-long friendship with Queen Elizabeth II, and the time she called him, unexpectedly, at 2:30 a.m.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
The Man Who Listens to Horses (Book)
item.media:credit: David Butow for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Roberts and a photo of the queen. “When the queen was with horses, she was a horse person,” he said.
